I'm excited to announce my upcoming residency "See Me As I Am”, a year-long celebration at Lincoln Center bringing together many of my musical expressions—through jazz, opera, chamber music, orchestral music, film scores, and more! 

The multi-disciplinary collaboration launches in March and includes events with @filmlinc, @jazzdotorg, @juilliardschool, @lincolncenter, @metopera, @nyphilharmonic, and @nypl_lpa.
Back home after a small tour. @dginyard @charlesaltura @tayloreigsti @markwhitfieldjr @tiq_music

Next week in Dallas, I will be joining forces with the @DallasSymphony and singers @kikislacksoprano & @nichonewt performing music from "Fire Shut Up In My Bones". Tickets available at:  www.dallassymphony.org

I am both humbled and honored to have won a Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording for ‘Fire Shut Up In My Bones.' I was not able to attend this year due to being on the road with the maestro himself, @herbiehancock @recordingacademy #herbiehancock #Grammys2023 #GrammyWinner #FireShutUpInMyBones

To say that I am honored and excited would be an understatement. “See Me As I Am: Lincoln Center’s Year-Long Celebration” will explore my artistic work from jazz, opera, chamber music, orchestral music, film and more with such respected collaborators as Jazz at Lincoln Center, The Juilliard School, the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, The Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, and the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. The year-long celebration begins in March 2023.  You can join us for the Met premiere of Champion, my opera based on the story of boxer Emile Griffith,  from April 10 through May 13. To learn more about the schedule of events, please see the link in the bio.

#LincolnCenter #MetOpera #AJazzLife #Champion #EmileGriffith

Pictured: Blanchard at the Met premiere of Fire Shut Up in My Bones in 2021 (rcallahanphoto / Met Opera)

After a whirlwind tour of Europe, we are heading to Denison University in Ohio on March 2nd & 3rd for two concerts in connection with the "Gordon Parks & Contemporaries through the Lens" exhibition at the Denison Museum. The exhibition celebrates the photographic, journalism, and poetic work of the great Gordon Parks.

#vailseries #gordonparks #denisonmusem #terenceblanchardecollective #turtleislandquartet #andrewfscott  #ecollective #DenisonUniversityVailSeries  #DenisonUniversity

My Monday Motivation is the steely determination captured in the eyes of Muhammed Ali in this image by the great photographer Gordon Parks. Parks documented urban life, civil rights, poverty, celebrities, musicians and athletes, creating an archival platform of our history.  A true renaissance man, Parks was also a composer, author and filmmaker with notable credits like The Learning Tree, based on his bestselling semiautobiographical novel and Shaft (1971). During these challenging times, a steely determination is needed to tell our stories, enter any ring, create art and even walk down the street.

#MuhammedAli #SteelyDetermination #OurHistory #Champion #InTheRing #GordonParks #RopeADope #SoManyStoriesToTell #Art  #SeeYourself #Jazz #Absence 

Learn more about Gordon Parks at GordonParksFoundation.org
Image Credit: Gordon Parks Foundation, Untitled (Muhammad Ali), Miami Beach, Florida, 1970⁠
https://www.instagram.com/p/Ck9RRcBDcZk/

Join us for "The Movie Music of Spike Lee & Terence Blanchard," a night showcasing my long collaboration with the legendary filmmaker Spike Lee, Sat/Mar 18, 2023 - 8:00 PM at Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles. The musical scores at the heart of Lee’s films come to life, featuring my all-star quintet, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and special guest vocalists Lalah Hathaway and Tarriona “Tank” Ball, plus specially curated images of the films projected throughout the performance.  Looking forward to seeing all my LA peeps.
#LAPhil, #SpikeLee #MovieMusic #Life #Jazz #thinktank20 #lalahhathaway #
Learn more: https://www.laphil.com/events/performances/1873/2023-03-18/the-movie-music-of-spike-lee-terence-blanchard

For more info & tickets, visit: @SavannahMusicFestival  #SavannahGA #SMF2023#MusicFestival #Music #VisitSavannah #TurtleIslandQuartet #ECollective #WayneShorter #Jazz #MusicLiberates

It’s always hard when we lose a hero and musician who changed the course of music but this one really stings because he was also a friend and mentor. A joyful human being who changed all of our lives. RIP Wayne.

Took the E Collective and Turtle Island to meet Wayne before recording our Album that honors him to also tell him how much we loved him and what he meant to us. Also we received inspiration from him before the session.

Earlier this week, I had the opportunity to join director James Robinson and Michael Heaston, the Met’s Assistant General Manager of Artistic, along with the cast of Champion for the first time. We  presented an overview of Champion - the production, design concepts, set model, costumes, story and music.

Champion is the story of boxer Emile Griffith, starring bass-baritone Ryan Speedo Green  as the closeted young prizefighter who kills his rival in the ring—an act that haunts Emile for the rest of his life. Met Music Director Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducts the Met premiere.

Champion opens on April 10. In cinemas and Live at Home on April 29.

#Champion #MetOpera #TerenceBlanchard #Jazz #EmileGriffith 

Photos by Rubén Sosa / Met Opera

We are less than one week away from the Met premiere of Champion. 

James Robinson’s dramatic staging features bass-baritones Ryan Speedo Green (@speedogreen) and Eric Owens (@EricOwensOpera) as the tormented prizefighter Emile Griffith at different points in his life, alongside  a cast that includes soprano Latonia Moore (@lamoooore)and mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe (sblythe327). Met Music Director Yannick Nézet-Séguin (@nezetseguin) conducts.

Champion's journey began in 2013 when it was co-commissioned by Opera Theatre St. Louis (@operatheatrestl) and Jazz St. Louis (@jazzstlouis). Now, in 2023, it will premiere @MetOpera, one of the most critical opera stages in the world. I am very proud and would like to thank all of the creative talent and forces who have been part of this journey.

Champion opens April 10. In cinemas and Live at Home on April 29.

Photos by Jonathan Tichler / Met Opera

#Champion #MetOpera #TerenceBlanchard

🌟 NEW EPISODE ALERT 🌟
Tune into my interview on Speaking Soundly, a cool podcast featuring backstage conversations with musicians. We discuss how I feel about becoming the first Black composer commissioned by The Metropolitan Opera since it opened in 1883, my experience and the great lessons that I learned from Art Blakey and The Jazz Messengers, and my film work, including 17 collaborations with Spike Lee. 

LISTEN & FOLLOW THE SHOW:
➡️ Apple Podcasts: https://apple.co/3C8Tv7X
➡️ Spotify: https://spoti.fi/3dwEnad
📸: Cedric Angeles

Show Announcement: Excited to perform at the 66th Monterey Jazz Festival in Monterey, California, Sept.  22-24, 2023. This year’s Grammy-winning headliners also include Herbie Hancock, Thundercat, Dianne Reeves Music, Snarky Puppy,  Jamie Cullum, Charles Lloyd, John Scofield, Terri Lyne Carrington, Christian McBride, and the Recording Academy’s Best New Artist for 2023, Samara Joy.

Tickets went on sale on April 14th at http://ow.ly/WxEi50NJXOZ. Single Day Tickets will be available on May 5. 

Co-founded by Jimmy Lyons & Ralph J. Gleason in 1958, Monterey Jazz Festival is the longest continuously-running jazz festival in the world.

#MJF66
#MontereyJazzFestival
#MontereyJazz

Reminder: Today,  Saturday, April 15, at 3PM, join me and bass-baritone Ryan Speedo Green @speedogreen, boxing brand @Everlast, social-justice pioneers @RISEtoWIN, change-makers @NativeSonNow, and the Metropolitan Opera at Aaron Davis Hall at City College Center for the Arts as they uncover the grit and guts it takes to become a top-flight athlete, a professional opera singer, and a Grammy Award–winning composer.

This community-focused event brings together audiences, families, and aspiring athletes and singers in Harlem and Upper Manhattan for a panel discussion and a performance by Ryan Speedo Green, who stars as the young prizefighter Emile Griffith in the Met premiere of Blanchard’s Champion. Attendance is free and open to the public, but advance registration is required.

Visit the link in bio to register. [LINK: bit.ly/championringleaders]

Champion runs  through May 13. In cinemas and Live at Home on April 29.

Photo by @ZenithRichards / Met Opera
#MetOpera #Champion #TerenceBlanchard

social_posts.post_text:
Champion Opening Night Album #1: Thank you to everyone for attending the premiere of Champion and making this one of the most memorable nights of my life. Friends and family, Met supporters and artists, opera lovers and many others attended the premiere, cast party, and dinner. 

Thanks to the Met and Shannon Finney  @shannonphotogal for sharing these great photos. 

#Champion #MetOpera  #EmileGriffith #Art #Jazz  #Family #NYC

Champion Opening Night Album #2: Champion is an artistic reflection of Emile Griffith's life; the premiere  brought out opera lovers, donors, artists, friends, family, and so many of my supporters from the early days of my career. I am very proud of all the creative forces that contributed to this project and I invite everyone to come out and see Champion. 

Thanks to the Met and Rose Callahan for sharing these great photos @rcallahanphoto @lastnightatthemet 

#Champion #MetOpera #EmileGriffith #Art #Jazz #Family #NYC #Opera
My daughter @tomgirl504ever just made the NY Times for what she wore to the premiere
Obviously the brains in the family. Getting her Masters today in Creative and Critical Writing. My youngest Jordan Blanchard aka @yourunclecozy So Proud of MY BABY!!!

I am honored to receive the George Peabody Medal for Outstanding Contributions to Music and Dance in America. Arts education helps our country and world flourish. I will address the graduates during the Peabody Conservatory’s 2023 Graduation ceremonies on Wednesday, May 24.

 The George Peabody Medal is the highest honor bestowed by the Peabody Institute of John Hopkins University and has been presented annually since 1980. So proud to join Herbie Hancock, Renée Fleming, Tori Amos, Leon Fleisher, Yo-Yo Ma, Jessye Norman, Roy Haynes, Quincy Jones, Wynton Marsalis, Marilyn Horne, André Watts, Ella Fitzgerald, and Leonard Bernstein as previous George Peabody Medal winners

Attached are some images of the Peabody Jazz Ensemble in rehearsal. Photos by Ben Johnson. Courtesy of the Peabody Institute.

Join us in cinemas worldwide today, April 29, for the Live in HD transmission of Champion! 

Here is the Link to find your theater: https://www.metopera.org/season/in-cinemas/?utm_source=IGBio&utm_medium=Social&utm_campaign=2122_ss 

Select audiences who do not have access to participating movie theaters may be eligible for the Met’s streaming platform, The Met: Live at Home. Visit metopera.org/liveathome to learn more.

Brown to learn more about the design team's incredible work—including costume designer Montana Levi Blanco and boxing consultant Michael Bentt—bringing this vivid new production to life. Heading home to New Orleans this weekend  to play the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, the most eclectic jazz festival in the world. I will be closing out the WWOZ Jazz Tent on Sat. May 6 with the E-Collective and the Turtle Island Quartet. Hope to see all my NOLA peeps and musicians!!
 
#jazzfest #wwoz_neworleans  #DownInNewOrleans

Getting excited about our late-night shows at Chickie Wah Wah's this Friday, May 5th. Late-night jams are a thing during Jazz Fest in New Orleans and we are ready to light up Canal St. Hope to see ya'll there! 
#Jazz #OnlyInNewOrleans #TurtleIslandQuartet

Jazz Fest weekend in New Orleans is a marathon,  several sprints and a few laps in a musical pool. Our weekend began with two standing-room-only shows at Chickie Wah Wah. It was our first time playing the intimate venue and although the Turtle Island Quartet barely fit on the stage, the audiences were great. I want to thank Steve Rehage and his partners for having us. Next was our closing set on Saturday in the  WWOZ Jazz Tent at the fairgrounds; the tent was filled to capacity with music lovers of every stripe. Then on Sunday, I sat in with the legendary Herbie Hancock and his amazing band. It was truly a special moment to join Herbie in New Orleans. Jazz Fest 2023 was one for the history books. Thanks to everyone who made this all possible. 

 #jazzlegends #musicicons #nojazzfest  #tourlife #chickiewahwah #herbiehancock #neworleans

Meditation is an integral part of my daily practice. I had the good fortune to record an episode for Meditative Story. This original podcast combines first-person storytelling with mindfulness prompts that are woven into a narrative and surrounded by original music. In my Meditative Story, I reflect on growing up in New Orleans, my teachers, bandleaders and confidants who became my mentors and shaped my future. The story came full circle when I became a mentor to other young musicians. I encourage you to listen and check out some of the other episodes. I hope this helps you with your mindfulness practice. 
Here is the link to my episode: https://link.chtbl.com/TerenceBlanchard_Guest 
#Breathe #JazzLife #MeditativeStory

This was so unexpected and totally an awesome moment. Receiving a championship belt from @wbcboxing council for bringing attention to the life of Emile Griffith. Thank you Jill Diamond chair of WBC Cares for this honor. Thanks to my dude @themichaelbentt for bringing Emile’s story to me and for making the presentation of the belt happen. Thank you @metopera
RIP Bill Lee we all will miss you and owe you for opening the door for a lot us of us. Thank you

Rest Well, Ms. Turner and may your Spirit soar!

“Jazz music itself is an example of changing poison into medicine. African Americans created jazz, a great medicine for people’s hearts, out of the poisonous experience of slavery. Jazz developed from African culture, gospel music, and blues to lift up the spirits of oppressed people, and now it brings joy to people the world over.” ― Tina Turner, Happiness Becomes You: A Guide to Changing Your Life for Good

I am thrilled to collaborate with Disney’s Imagineering team on scoring the music for the queue line of Tiana’s Bayou Adventure, a new attraction coming to Disney World and Disneyland.  Based on the successful film, “The Princess and the Frog,” where I had so much fun performing the trumpet parts of Louis the Alligator, Tiana’s Bayou Adventure will feature the rhythmic sounds of New Orleans music. I am also very excited to have fellow New Orleans musician PJ Morton who is composing a new original song on this project. 
Read more at http://spr.ly/6181Otubd

I am excited about working on Tiana’s Bayou Adventure, Disney’s upcoming attraction at Disney World and Disneyland. Being a part of the team along with PJ Morton that creates the musical landscape for this attraction is historic. Here are some images from last week’s gathering of Walt Disney’s Imagineering team led by Carmen Smith, Charita Carter, John Dennis, and Ted Robledo at Dooky Chase’s Restaurant in New Orleans. Their respect for the power of New Orleans music and culture inspires me to create an epic soundscape that reflects the essence of New Orleans. Also, I got to have dinner with Edgar and Stella Chase Reese, and hear incredible stories about their mother and father, Mrs. Leah and Dooky Chase.  And I got  to meet Tiana in person!
Courtesy of T3 @jrei.oliver @liv_love_laugh_ @tomgirl504ever @yourunclecozy

SFJAZZ announces the appointment of seven-time Grammy Winner and two-time Academy Award Nominee Terence Blanchard as Executive Artistic Director. Terence will lead the organization’s artistic programming and guide its overall creative direction. Blanchard’s appointment comes as SFJAZZ Founder Randall Kline prepares to step down this year from the organization he founded in 1983.

Blanchard is a renowned composer, bandleader, and trumpet player who has been a consistent artistic force for making powerful musical statements for over 40 years. From his stint with Art Blakey & The Jazz Messengers to writing scores for Spike Lee and other films, he is unique in the jazz world as an artist whose creative endeavors go far beyond the genre into film scoring, crafting television series soundscapes, and conceiving grand operas that have been recognized at the highest levels of art appreciation. 

Said Blanchard, “I am honored and excited to become a part of such an amazing and historic institution. SFJAZZ has meant so much to the development of America’s greatest artform. I am looking forward to collaborating with the staff while also bringing my own ideas about how to move our music forward and continue the SFJAZZ mission to explore the full spectrum of jazz—from its origins to its diverse and evolving expressions around the world today. I cannot wait to continue this journey.”

To learn more, visit SFJAZZ.org

I am honored and excited to announce that I have been appointed the Executive Artistic Director of SFJAZZ. This amazing and historic institution has strengthened jazz, America’s greatest art form.  In this position, I will lead the organization’s artistic programming and guide its overall creative direction.  I look forward to collaborating with the staff while bringing my own ideas on moving the music forward and continuing the SFJAZZ mission to explore the full spectrum of jazz—from its origins to its diverse and evolving expressions around the world today. I cannot wait to continue this journey.

I would like to thank and recognize SFJAZZ Founder Randall Kline, whose visionary zeal for jazz fortified the art form in San Francisco and worldwide. 
 
I am joining SFJAZZ as it celebrates its 40th Anniversary and the 10th Birthday of the award-winning SFJAZZ Center and as it prepares for the 40th San Francisco Jazz Festival starting June 7, with 42 concerts in 12 days, and the 2023-2024 season beginning September 7. 
 
Here we go….

To learn more visit SFJAZZ.org

New incoming SFJAZZ Executive Artistic Director Terence Blanchard discusses in his own words, why he’s excited to lead the organization’s artistic programming and guide its overall creative direction.

To learn more, visit SFJAZZ.org

Here is a nice throwback photo of my time with Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers. My time in this band was like going to Harvard, Oxford and Timbuktu's most advanced temple of learning combined. In 2020 SFJAZZ Magazine wrote a piece, "Jazz Messengers Connection," about the band's role as an incubator of talent. Check it out here: https://www.sfjazz.org/onthecorner/the-jazz-messengers-connection/ 

 (L-R: Tim Williams, Jean Toussaint, Terence Blanchard, Donald Harrison)

Tickets are on sale and are available for purchase here: https://bit.ly/3NAxAMe.

social_posts.post_text:
Our show at the Stanford Jazz Workshop Jazz Festival on Saturday, June 24th at the Bing Concert Hall celebrates the music of Wayne Shorter and features the E-Collective with these incredible musicians -- Taylor Eigsti, piano; Charles Altura, guitar;  David Ginyard, bass and Mark Whitfield, Jr., drums. Also, we perform with the talented Turtle Island String Quartet featuring David Balakrishnan, violin; Gabriel Terracciano, violin; Benjamin von Gutzeit, viola and Naseem Alatrash, cello.

Looking forward to seeing you all at the Stanford Jazz Workshop! #LiveJazz

MONDAY MEDITATION- COMPASSION

“We are here; we exist, and we have the right to exist. 

The greatest degree of inner tranquility comes from the development of love and compassion. 

Compassionate human affection is really important. The more compassionate our mind is, the better our brain functions. Compassion gives us inner strength, it gives us self-confidence and that reduces fear, which, in turn, keeps our mind calm. 

Compassion has two functions: it causes our brain to function better and it brings inner strength.” Dalai Lama

When I think of Emile Griffith’s struggle to separate his boxing life from his personal life and how he could not openly share his triumphs and pitfalls with a partner, I think of compassion. Imagine a world where Emile received compassion instead of fear.

 As Pride month comes to an end, I share a picture of Emile in Greenwich Village in 2007 with some of his friends from the Stonewall Rebellion Veterans Association, which he helped to found and finance.

You can read more about Emile’s life here: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/11/nyregion/emile-griffith-boxer-champion.html
 
Dalai Lama- Compassion as the Source of Happiness
https://www.dalailama.com/messages/compassion-and-human-values/compassion-as-the-source-of-happiness
So this finally came today. For Fire Shut Up In My Bones
It’s been like that. Having so much fun.
My kids out and about ( even though one is missing). Love them to death and so proud of all of them. @jrei.oliver @liv_love_laugh_ @tomgirl504ever @yourunclecozy

A new episode of #Swagger drops this Friday on AppleTV+. I had the great opportunity to work on this popular series with director Reggie Rock Bythewood. The drama explores the world of youth basketball, the players, their families and coaches who walk the fine line between dreams and ambition and opportunism and corruption. As Reggie says, “Swagger” is about humanity and having a cause bigger than yourself.  Watch and see how my music is a part of the storytelling.

Season 1 and Season 2 episodes are available to stream on Apple TV+ with a new episode coming out this Friday. Learn more at apple.co/swagger

 #Swagger #ReggieRockBythewood #RockTheFilm

Like music, visual art brings joy, and helps us to reflect on and escape everyday life. Frederick J. Brown (1945-2012) was a New York City and Arizona-based American artist whose work referenced history, music, the urban fabric, religion, and spiritual themes.  Brown’s work ranged from figurative to abstract to musicians' portraits. His contribution to the resurgence of expressive figuration made Brown a defining artist of the late 70’s,  80’s, and 90’s.  His work can be seen in public spaces around the country, including  Xavier Univerisity in my hometown of New Orleans. Brown’s work is held in the collection of the Smithsonian and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, to name a few. 

I have lived with some of Brown’s abstract work in my home for many years. After returning from a tour, I gaze at his work,  reflect on life and smile. 

@frederickjbrownart. Learn more about Frederick J. Brown at https://ow.ly/UxHQ50Pqm5G

Image 1: Untitled 1979.  Oil on linen, 46 x 32 in.. Collection of the Frederick J. Brown Trust

Image 2: Untitled 1977. Acrylic, ink and pencil on paper.25 1/2 x 19 3/4 in. Collection of the Frederick J. Brown Trust

As a fellow composer for jazz and film projects, please check out Stanley Clarke's August 12th concert at the SFJAZZ Center in San Francisco, where he will be revisiting his score for John Singleton’s ambitious landmark 1993 drama Poetic Justice, which starred Janet Jackson and Tupac Shakur. Roger Ebert said, "...Poetic Justice unwinds like a road picture from the early 1970s, in which the characters are introduced and then set off on a trip that becomes a journey of discovery.” SFJAZZ's live concert will feature Stanley's quartet alongside a string ensemble. This show is a rare opportunity to celebrate Singleton’s Oscar and Golden Globe nominated masterpiece and to rehear the music 30 years later in a live setting.

For tickets and information, visit SFJAZZ.org

See you soon at the SFJAZZ Center!
First day on the job. Excited to be here. Cool and creative people working to provide great experiences for all who come through.

I am proud to announce that Robin Burgess, President of Burgess Management and Partner at Over The Garage Productions will be joining me at SFJAZZ in the role of Artistic Project Manager. In this role, Robin will be responsible for working closely with the SFJAZZ team to bring together a wide array of stakeholders to foster an environment of inspiration that supports the creative process at SFJAZZ.

Join me for this exclusive matinee screening on 10/8 at SFJAZZ of director Dorsay Alavi’s new 3-part documentary film Zero Gravity, tracing the life and music of the late genius Wayne Shorter.  Over a decade in the making, Zero Gravity is constructed in three parts, corresponding to three major periods in the saxophonist and composer’s momentous life.

Tickets are currently on sale at: https://www.sfjazz.org/tickets/productions/23-24/wayne-shorter-zero-gravity/

#SFJAZZ #AJAZZLIFE

The New York Times highlights new SFJAZZ Executive Artistic Director Terence Blanchard ‘Pushing Jazz Forward From A New Perch’: 

“A six-time Grammy winner, Blanchard possesses one of the most commanding and slippery trumpet styles in jazz, and for almost a decade he has led one of its most reliable ensembles, the E-Collective, full of musicians a couple of decades his junior. He has written and recorded over 40 film scores, including for most of Spike Lee’s movies. Despite being a conservatory dropout himself, he has become a leading educator, helping shape programs at U.C.L.A., the University of Miami and the Herbie Hancock Institute of Jazz. And in recent years, he has made headlines for the back-to-back Met premieres of his two operas, “Fire Shut Up in My Bones” and “Champion.”

All of which makes for relevant job training for the new role. “The thing that I’ve always loved about SFJazz is that they don’t treat the music like it’s a fossil,” Blanchard said in a phone interview. “It’s a living, breathing, ongoing thing. And they respect young artists who are bringing something different to the table.”

Blanchard is taking the reins directly from SFJazz’s founder, Randall Kline, who has run the organization since it started in 1982, always with a passion for what’s next. “I remember thinking how much I love that dude,” Blanchard said. “He was just a serious music lover who happened to be a promoter.”

Full Read in our LINKTREE

I am excited to return to Istanbul in the Republic of Türkiye to perform at the Akbank Jazz Festival  on Sept. 29.  I've been touring Türkiye, as the country of Turkey is now officially known, for many years, and I am always honored and grateful for thier commitment to jazz. The Akbank Festival presents  prominent jazz figures,  emerging next-gen artists,  panels, workshops, film screening sessions, and social responsibility projects. 

I hope to see you at the Zorlu PSM, Turkcell Platinum Stage

They will perform material from their cool new duo album 'Lean In', which blends Bossa Nova, R&B, West African roots and more.

SFJAZZ Dialogues: Wynton Marsalis and Terence Blanchard

Legendary trumpeter and Jazz At Lincoln Center’s artistic director Wynton Marsalis catches up with his friend and executive artistic director at SFJAZZ Terence Blanchard. They share fond childhood memories, discuss the intersection of philosophy and jazz, talk about their future plans for institutional collaboration, and preview the livestream featuring Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis on Fridays Live October 6, part of SFJAZZ At Home.

Full Video at SFJAZZ.org/AtHome

SFJAZZ DIALOGUES A sit down with the artists featured on Fridays Live, sharing stories and insights behind the music. This conversation is featured in the June 2023 Edition of the SFJAZZ Magazine.

Last weekend at SFJAZZ, I had the unique pleasure to speak with director Dorsay Alavi to explore Zero Gravity, the 3-part documentary that traces the life and music of the late genius Wayne Shorter. Over a decade in the making, Zero Gravity is constructed in three parts, corresponding to three major periods in Shorter's momentous life. 

I was honored to discuss the film,  Wayne's greatness and his influence on me and jazz. Thanks to all the folks who came to #SFJAZZ for the pre-screening discussion and film. Looking forward to many more. 

#SFJAZZ #ZeroGravity #WayneShorter #IDareYou

Bringing "Film Scores Live" to the  Lied Center in Lawrence, Kansas this Thursday, November 2nd, joining me will be the E-Collective and members of the Lawrence Community Orchestra.  To start exploring my film music, I will join Oscar-winner Kevin Willmott for a conversation about balancing social justice and entertainment and the social impact of music and movies on November 1st at 4pm.  The talk is free and open to the public. Learn more at lied.ku.edu.

Bringing a new suite of music from Fire Shut Up in My Bones to Decamera this Friday, November 10 at the Cullen Theater, Wortham Theater Center in Houston.  Joining me on this special presentation is my band the E-Collective,  the Grammy Award-winning Turtle Island Quartet and vocalists Nicholas Newton and Adrienne Danrich.  Based on the memoir by Charles Blow, Fire Shut Up in My Bones tells the true coming-of-age story of a young man growing up in the face of great adversity and forging his personal identity.  The opera made history in 2021 as the first opera to be staged by a Black composer at the Metropolitan Opera.

For ticket information visit, boxoffice@dacamera.com

Today like most I’m thankful for my family and friends who have given me so much in life that it can’t be measured. Today though I’m also very thankful for these heroic black men who taught me everything and have taught and inspired so many I had to post these photos of them. Howard Swanson is a great composer who taught two of my teachers. Roger Dickerson and Hale Smith. These men are American heroes who’ve never gotten their flowers. I try as much as I can to let people know of them and how much they’ve influenced so many of us. So today I’m also very thankful to be propped up by these amazingly strong shoulders forever grateful of being in the presence. Happy Thanksgiving 🍁 Everyone
3 generations of Blanchards hanging on Thanksgiving watching football. Can’t get any better. @jrei.oliver @liv_love_laugh_ @tomgirl504ever @yourunclecozy

I had a chance to chat with the Nobhill Gazette in San Francisco about my new role as Artistic Director of SFJazz and I wanted to share this piece with everyone because San Fransisco is one of the greatest cities in the world. I have been going there since the 80's and am ready to work with the youth to demystify jazz, continue the unique programming and help to strengthen the city through SFJazz. Can you tell that I am excited? Well, you can read the piece yourself.

My daughter @yourunclecozy found my first recording ever done with Art Blakey in 1982 (where I’m called a 19 year old drummer) in a record shop in London and when she realized it was my first she ran back to the store before closing and got it for me for Christmas a very cool gift indeed. Hope your Christmas is as cool as mine. Enjoy the holiday season.

Here we go 2024! I am excited to share SFJAZZ At Home 2.0, where you can watch over 25 full-length SFJAZZ concerts filmed over the past ten years. Concerts include Diane Reeves,  Christian McBride Quintet, MeShelle Ndegocello, Preservation Hall Jazz Band, John Scofield and Lettuce, to name a few. Every week, a new concert will be added to the On-Demand Library, and we're launching four new video series packed with stories and information from the world's foremost artists.  Plus, the weekly Friday Live broadcasts will continue. 

Browse the new features, including ten highlights from the On-Demand Library.  You can learn more at SFJAZZ.org/AtHome and download the SFJAZZ At Home App at: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/sfjazz-at-home/id1549053358 

SFJAZZ, Watch anytime, anywhere!

#SFJAZZ #LiveJazz
